posts.name: Daniel H
posts.cooked:
I am trying to help my team figure out an issue they are having with the REV MAXSwerve drive train. They are having issues where all 4 Spark MAX controllers and giving a sensor fault upon enabling the robot without any input being given. The faults can be cleared but pop back up after enabling. I have had them check all connections and they are fairly confident it is not a connection issue but I am not there with them to troubleshoot. Has anyone had this issue before or have any ideas for what I should suggest for them next? I’ve gone through code and as much as I could remotely, but am out of ideas.

Any help is appreciated!

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
Is it all the rotation controllers, all the drive controllers, all 8, or some other subset of them?

Do you have anything connected to the 10-pin sensor header at the top? If so, what?

posts.name: Daniel H
posts.cooked: Just all the rotation controllers, sorry. And yes they have the AbsoluteEncoders connected to a breakout board in the 10 pin sensors

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: Which encoders and which breakout boards?  If it’s what I suspect, my team found the exact same issue last night

posts.name: Daniel H
posts.cooked:
It would be the REV Through Bore Encoder

And the REV SPARK MAX Data Port Breakout Board

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
How did you wire the encoder to the breakout board? And specifically which breakout board?

I assume you’re trying to use it as an absolute encoder, right?  If you wired the A/B channels to it as well, those are internally connected to the same pins as the motor sensor cable (the braided one thats hardwired to the NEO/NEO550).  Doing so results in both sensors (throughbore and motor-internal) returning signal and confusing the sparkmax.  In absolute mode, the ONLY pins you need are power (maybe?), ground, and the PWM /Abs signal.

posts.name: Daniel H
posts.cooked:
It’s just connected to the absolute encoder adapter (breakout board) My large confusion is that it is essentially exactly the same setup we had last year and I’m not quite sure what has changed.

Yes, it is being used as an absolute encoder and the ribbon just goes directly into the built in connector on the adapter.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: Thats why i was asking for specifics.  REV makes several boards that look rather similar so I wanted to confirm

posts.name: Daniel H
posts.cooked: Yeah, sorry I was unclear in my original post

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
Okay, so just confirming…

You have the Absolute Encoder Adapter board ( Absolute Encoder Adapter - REV Robotics ) not the Alternate Encoder Adapter board ( Alternate Encoder Adapter - 2 Pack - REV Robotics ), right?

link_counts.title: Alternate Encoder Adapter - 2 Pack - REV Robotics

posts.name: Daniel H
posts.cooked: Correct, they just have the COTS REV MaxSwerve Kit (REV-21-3005) which comes with the Absolute Encoder Adapter (REV-11-3326) not (REV-11-1881), though they do seem incredibly similar from what I can see.

My team is having a similar problem, so I want to chime in here. Our turning motor controllers are flashing a sensor fault for some reason. We have the right encoder boards and we’ve double checked our wiring, but for some reason the sensor faults just happen on those 4 controllers. I’m hoping someone smarter than I will be able to help.

posts.name: Ben riemer
posts.cooked:
For future reference and if yall are still having issues, this problem is a result of jumpered and shorted pins or an incorrect connection on the absolute encoder board. These issues are typically caused by poor soldering or soldering the wrong input to the wrong pin. My team had this problem with the srx mag encoders and making custom adapter cables to a sparkmax with the correct pinout resolved the issue.

It may also be useful to note that the port on the bottom of the absolute encoder breakout board is significantly smaller than the port on the sparkmax motor controller and can be shifted left or right by 1-2 pins either direction since it was made to be compatible with srx style cables which have a space either side of the pins used for the rails on the crimp on connector. This shift may also cause this issue since the absolute encoder is necessary for the motor controller to function but the requirement is only set in code when the robot is enabled, meaning you can have the same behavior if the encoder does not receive power, is unplugged, or broken.

Tldr: ensure the encoder breakout board is centered on the pins because it is possible (and easy) to install it wrong. Additionally, you should ensure that any solder joints aren’t bridging or shorting connections and are made to the correct pins and that the encoder is receiving power and actually works.

posts.name: Ben riemer
posts.cooked:
Check the rev hardware client and if one of the “hard limits” are reached that means the board is improperly set up. This is the most common error for srx encoders but you may find there are different pins shorting on your end.

Or the boards are off center which is unfortunately something that can happen with them

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: we encountered this failure mode recently with the Spark Max port: it’s impossible to tell if you’re plugging the board in wrong, since the plug is so much smaller than the socket.  is there a standard workaround?  some sort of 3d printed shim?
